article: In my memory, the large pickle jar sat on the floor beside the dresser in my parents' bedroom. Dad would always _ his coins into the jar before he went to bed: first the jar was _ and there was a merry jingle and then a _ sound as it was full. Every time Dad took them to the bank, he would look at me _ . "You'll go to college on pennies, son. This old mill town's not going to hold you back and you will _ here for a better life." No matter how _ things got, Dad continued to drop his coins into the jar. Even during the summer when Dad got _ from the mill and hadn't enough money to get food for us, not a _ penny was taken from the jar. Years passed, and I finished college. Once, while visiting my parents, I noticed the pickle jar, which had _ its purpose, gone. My dad was a man of _ words, and never lectured me on determination, faith and alike. The pickle jar had taught me all these _ far more convincingly. When I got married, I told my wife Susan about the _ of the pickle jar. The first Christmas after our daughter Jessica was born, we _ at my parents'. After dinner, Susan carried Jessica into my parents' _ to diaper (......) her.  When Susan came back, there was strange excitement in her _ . Avoiding being noticed by my parents, she _ led me into the bedroom. "Look," her eyes _ me to a spot beside the dresser. To my _ , the old pickle jar stood there, as if it had never been _ , with the bottom already covered with coins. I knew it was for my daughter. I was too choked with _ feelings to speak. I just dug down into my pocket and dropped all my coins into the jar.
